title: Inconsistent compiler choice behavior with external packages
body:
If I define an external package with a general spec and `buildable: False`, I would expect if I am explicit when choosing the compiler on the command line, it should register that external under the chosen compiler but it doesn't. This is inconsistent behavior because if I install a package with a dependency on the external, it registers it with the compiler chosen.

### Steps to reproduce the issue

```console
$ cat packages.yaml 
packages:
  cmake:
    paths:
      cmake@3.11.1: /usr/local/Cellar/cmake/3.11.1
    buildable: False
  all:
    compiler: [clang, gcc]

$ spack install cmake %gcc
==> cmake@3.11.1 : externally installed in /usr/local/Cellar/cmake/3.11.1
==> cmake@3.11.1 : generating module file
==> cmake@3.11.1 : registering into DB

$ spack find
==> 1 installed packages.
-- darwin-sierra-x86_64 / clang@9.0.0-apple ---------------------
cmake@3.11.1

$ spack install --fake yaml-cpp %gcc
==> cmake@3.11.1 : externally installed in /usr/local/Cellar/cmake/3.11.1
==> cmake@3.11.1 : generating module file
==> cmake@3.11.1 : registering into DB
==> Installing yaml-cpp
==> Building yaml-cpp [CMakePackage]
==> Successfully installed yaml-cpp
  Fetch: .  Build: 0.08s.  Total: 0.08s.

$ spack find
==> 3 installed packages.
-- darwin-sierra-x86_64 / clang@9.0.0-apple ---------------------
cmake@3.11.1

-- darwin-sierra-x86_64 / gcc@8.1.0 -----------------------------
cmake@3.11.1  yaml-cpp@0.6.2
```

If I define the specs more explicitly, it allows me to explicitly install using either compiler though:
```console
$ cat packages.yaml 
packages:
  cmake:
    paths:
      cmake@3.11.1%gcc: /usr/local/Cellar/cmake/3.11.1
      cmake@3.11.1%clang: /usr/local/Cellar/cmake/3.11.1
    buildable: False
  all:
    compiler: [clang, gcc]
```
